Journal Story: 16 boxes shipped to various hostels and post offices
60-65 pounds pre-hike training with Cathy.
Altitude 3782
It was 32 degrees at the start, warming up to 55.
The trail is in great shape.
12 miles to Woody Gap today.
It's much cooler today. Went from an elevation of 2500 to 4457. Going a couple more miles on the trail past Neil Gap and set up camp.

I want to thank my drivers, Stanley Olin-Dabrowski and Bill Ring for getting me to Georgia safe and sound and seeing me through my first couple of days of the hike. Thank you, it got me off to a great start.

A different site along the way! I stayed Friday night at Poplar Stamp Gap, I passed Low Gap Shelter which had been my planned stop for the day. I hadn't been able to communicate due to poor cell reception. Saturday I stayed at Tray Shelter. We had "trail magic" at Umicoi. Folks had driven 5 hours from Cullian, Alabama to serve us hikers burgers and hot dogs as we came by! A trail magic treat for sure.

I am a day ahead of my intended schedule. I made it to Top of Georgia hostel and was able to pick up my package of resupplies. I'm now moving on to Plum Orchard. I have gone a total of approximately 74 miles.
I left Plum Orchard this morning, very heavy rain with 45 mile per hour winds. I stopped around 1:00 pm and decided to stay the night at Muskrat Shelter. Everything is wet.

I've gone a total distance of 109 miles, I've adjusted today's distance to reflect. I don't have very good cell phone reception along the trail, so I am not able to update every day. This is the top of Albert Mountain.

I'm 2 days ahead of schedule, currently in Franklin, NC trying to get my hiking pole repaired. They are putting a splint on it for a temporary repair. Today was a dry day but rain is predicted for tomorrow. I received some outstanding news, my daughter Erin and Garrett got engaged, very happy.

Last night I stayed at Eric and Sofie's, I had a great meal, a shower and was able to wash my clothes. I want to say thank you so much to them both. They picked me up in town and brought me back to the trail this morning. I passed Wayah Bald around noon today. I'm at Cold Spring Shelter, I pitched the tent in the rain but am now inside and warm.
https://youtu.be/bK6HQqfBNk4

Today I climbed fire tower before going into N.O.C. The views from the top were breathtaking. I hope you enjoy the video posted below. I am having dinner at N.O.C. with some fellow Appalachian trail hikers, freight train, medicine man and two-thirds.https://youtu.be/T73xJVw7ruQ

Today I went to the top of Cheoah Bald,altitude 5000 ft. I am staying atÂ Brown Fork gap Shelter tonight and there was trail magic at Stecoah Gap. I have inserted the picture at Cheoah Bald, it was beautiful.

I'm spending the night at Fontana Dam. It was not my intended stop but I was unable to go to Birch Spring Gap because they closed the camp grounds due to bear. I will be heading into the Great Smoky Mountains tomorrow.
I hiked with a couple of other hikers today, Peanut and Tadpole. I'm currently at Russell Field Shelter in the Smokies, set up for the night. The temperature warmed up to 70 degrees.
I'm at Double Spring Gap Shelter. I've updated my miles again, went 16.8 today. I'm heading into town now.
This is the highest elevation on the trail, 6658 feet, so beautiful. I'm staying in Gatlinburg for the night. I will go to mass in the morning before I head back to the trail.

I went to morning mass at St. Mary's in Gatlinburg. Thank you to the Green family from Sacred Heart in Esopus for the suggestion. I went to breakfast with a couple of other hikers and then back to the trail.

Pictures never do justice to the beauty of the scenery that I see each day. I met people of all ages, young and old, from Germany and France today. I shared trail magic last night at Peck Corner with one of the guys from Germany. John from Nashville gave us Trillium beer, an IPA. I'm at Cosby Knob for the night, tomorrow to Standing Bear Farm and out of the Smokies.

Made it out of the Smoky Mountains and I am spending the night at Standing Bear. The attached photo is me outside the Standing Bear. I got a bunk and shower for $20. Along the way there was some trail magic from stick bridges and Kyle one mile before Standing Bear. I had a PBR and a hotdog. A Bear came into Crosby camp at 6:15 am. I heard a guy yell bear when it came right near his tent and they closed the camp site.
https://m.youtube.com/watch?feature=youtu.be&v=i_sJWveJ-tQ
This is a picture of a caged shelter that is from when I was in the Smokies.
An interesting spot when I was at Standing Bear.
There are about 10 or 12 folks sleeping on top of the mountain tonight. We are planning on getting up early to see the sunrise.
One of the many beautiful views from Max Patch.

It was a beautiful morning at the top of Max Patch. We did see a mother bear and two cubs go through last night, but they kept a distance. I'm currently at Laughing Heart Hostel in Hot Springs, NC. I picked up my packages. I want to put this message out there - Fab 10, did you make your commitment? Neil R. Post in my guest book, how you doing? I've been thinking about everyone. Also, thank you Stanley for the poles.
Breakfast at the diner before I head out to the trail.
I'm at Spring Mountain Shelter for the night. I was glad to have made it here just before the thunderstorm.
This is a view from Howard's Rock, a recently named Boulder honoring trail builder Howard McDonald.
I'm currently at Hog Back Ridge Shelter, I've gone a total of 316 miles to this point. I've eaten a plant called Ramp. It grows wild in the hills. It's a cross between garlic and onion.

I stopped at Big Baldy Shelter for lunch. I then enjoyed some trail magic from Elmo at Sam Gap, had some pretzels and bought a banana and a pint of blueberries. There were thunderstorms again this afternoon.
Natures beauty along the trail
I'm at Nobody's Business shelter for the night. It was a beautiful hike into it. I was happy to be able to pick up my resupplies here,
So many flowers along the past 21 miles
A striking field of flowers.
We had trail magic from Lola and Rob Casper. It's amazing how great folks have been.
I saw a bear as I was hiking today. He was about 200-250 pounds. Fortunately, he spotted me and ran. I set up camp after passing Iron Man Gap
Sunrise this morning before my hike.
These trail magic folks are from Michigan. I'm currently at Over Mountain barn, it is a revolutionary barn.
I'm at Mountaineer Falls Shelter for the night.

I was able to pick up my resupplies, shower and do wash at Kinora Hostel. It rained very hard today. I met folks from Andover, Maine. Their trail names are Honey and Bear. The have a hostel in Maine. They shared their pasta and sauce, that she had made, with me for dinner last night. They are through hikers from western Maine. I'm at Vandeventer Shelter now, still raining very hard.
I'm at Abingdon Gap Shelter for the night. I did 22 miles today. Damascus, Virginia is 9 miles from my location.

Bob Bunce drove up from Cary, North Carolina to bring us some trail magic. Bob spent the day with trail hugger and I, and drove us to a nice hotel for a warm shower and good meal. In addition, taking some weight from my pack.

Last night we stayed at Lost Mountain Shelter. Sunday we hiked with Bob Bunce, my running buddy from Fishkill. He's in great shape and when he gets back he will kick KDs butt! He lightened the load for me and tree hugger. We are coming up to wild ponies today. I had to get new hiking boots and am hoping that will help with the blisters. Other than that I am doing well! Thanks to Bob Bunce for all the support!
Early in the morning these cows came over for a visit.
Amazing wild ponies from the Grayson Highlands.
This is Tree Hugger with one of the ponies. I'm at Wise Shelter for the night, mile marker 503. It rained during the day today, but is clearing up this afternoon.
We are expecting rain later, but this morning it is beautiful. I'm heading to Trimpi Shelter.
This was my view from Walker mountain.
Making my way to Chat Field Shelter, mile marker 540.
We came across this sign as we were walking this morning.
This is the one room school house dating back to 1872.

Trail magic in the school provided by a local church. We walked just five miles this morning to Atkins, VA. We decided to get a room in town, do laundry and shower. I need to give my foot with the blisters a rest so I'm picking up Epsom salt to soak it. Hopefully that and the dry air for a day will help. I picked up my resupplies also. It has been raining a lot lately, but we hike through. Today is a nice day.
Heading in to Lick Creek Campsite

I passed this 600 mile mark on my way into Jenny Knobe. I'm currently at mile marker 603. I've been hiking with Cruise Control and Mover. Mover has 27,000 trail miles. I want to congratulate my daughters. Hayley graduated with her Ph.D. in cancer sciences from the University of Buffalo through Roswell. Erin ran her first marathon in Burlinton, VT today, her time was 4:34. So very proud of you both.
we are on our twelfth day of rain and they are calling for four more.
Beautiful stream where we were staying
The shelter where we were staying, mile marker 623.
Views of the shelter
Mmmmmm, what's cooking ladies?
Mountain Laurel on the way to Rice Field Shelter

The view from Rice Field Shelter. The trail magic worked out very well today. They had set up a tent and we were able to stay under it while we had some heavy rain. It stopped raining in the late afternoon.
We came across this memorial. Audie Leon Murphy was the recipient of three Purple Hearts.

Thursday we stayed at Warspur Shelter mile marker 668.5, then into Niday Shelter on Friday, mile marker 686.7. This is Cruise Control standing by Dragons Tooth. We are now at mile marker 703.4. There was rain today, but it was a nice day on Friday
Mile marker 710
I'm at Lambert's Meadow Shelter for the night. I'm continuing to hike with Cruise Control. Beautiful views today.

We experienced more amazing views while hiking along the Blue Ridge Parkway. It was one of the best days weather wise so far, sunny, mild breeze, temperatures in the low 70's. We had trail magic via Freight Train, his wife and sister were up from Savannah. We stopped at Bobbets Shelter for the night. I started my trip at around 190 pounds. I've lost about 20 pounds, now down to 170. Stanley, you had asked if there was anything I brought that I sent back. I bought a quilt for camping and sent back my sleeping bag, it's much lighter weight. Ok, stories to come!
We are heading into Cornelius Shelter. We passed this creek on our way in.
On our way into Glasgow.

One of the animals on the trail! We did have a copperhead in one of the shelters the other night. We all decided it was best to let him have it to himself. We slept on the ground in our tents, it worked out well for everyone!
On Friday, we passed mile marker 800 on our way into Brown Creek Shelter, mile marker 806.

It was a pleasant day as we headed to Priest Shelter, but then we were hit by heavy rain and hail. The blisters are still an issue. I've switched to using trail running shoes as opposed to my hiking boots. I have not taken any zero days yet. The shortest day that I hiked was on May 24 when we hiked 5 miles into town and got the hotel.

Today I hiked with Cruise Control and his daughter, Claire and future son-in-law, Marcus. We went from Reed Gap to Devils Backbone brewery. It was a tough hike but we enjoyed the beer at the end. We are setting up our tents in a field by the trail. 
Tony, I don't remember the powder you are referring to?
Stanley, the mail drops are spot on and the food is lasting until I get to the next stop (although I have lost 20 lbs, maybe I'm just rationing). Cathy is my trail angel and she's doing a fantastic job, watch for her informational book Entitled "how to be a good trail angel for dummies." The tent is showing some some wear and tear but it is holding up. The water was plentiful in the beginning of the trip but recently water has been more difficult to come by. The trail is very well marked. The oldest person I met was an 80 year old woman and another person who was 75 that has completed the trail twice whose trail name is slow poke. The youngest hikers appear to be in their twenties but I have come across some Boy and Girl Scouts. The Boy Scouts were practicing to do the rim to rim of the Grand Canyon. The Girl Scouts We're day hiking and I took their leftover food. The weather is definitely the biggest issue, especially the rain, heat and humidity. There is also some tough terrain and the website gut hooks is hard to follow. I haven't taken any 0 days, only a 5 mile day. I wouldn't be able to use the hammocks because there isn't a lot of good tree space and the covers for hammocks leak. I have not done any camp cooking and the bugs are brutal!
Photo from our trip to the brewery yesterday. Today, heading into Paul C Wolf Shelter.
Today I hiked 5 miles into Waynesboro, Virginia to go to urgent care about the blister. Got some antibiotics and new bandages. Staying at the hotel tonight.
I'm at Blackrock Hut for the night, mile marker 883.
We stopped for lunch at Pine Field Hut, then headed to Hightop for the night.

Cruise Control and I were picked up Friday morning by Joe Landi at Lewis Mountain Campground. His son Dan lives in the area with his family. We went to Dan's house where we were treated to a delicious meal, a shower and got to sleep comfortably in a bed for the night.
Thank you so much for the great hospitality and excellent dinner. We truly appreciate everything.
Before we headed back to the trail this morning, Joe brought me to the Holy Infant Church in Elkton where I received a blessing and holy communion.
Joe, Dan, Cruise and I hiked Big Meadows together today. Thank you again Joe. Cruise Control and I are camping next to the trail tonight, mile marker 936.

I'm at Gravel Springs Hut this morning, continuing through Virginia. We are planning on being in Harper's Ferry, Virginia by Wednesday or Thursday. I'm traveling approximately 10 days ahead of my intended schedule. Tony, thank you for the powder you sent to prevent blisters. I've been using it and have almost completed my course of antibiotics. I think the infection is beginning to heal. Thank you again.

Last night Cruise Control and I had dinner with my cousins Linda and Cooper. In the morning on our way into Front Royal, we saw an albino squirrel. We are out of Shenandoah. Thank you Linda and Cooper.

Last night I stayed in Rod Hollow Shelter at mile marker 994. Today I made it to David Lesser Memorial Shelter at mile marker 1015, passing the 1000 mile mark! I hiked part of the AT they call the Roller Coaster where it goes up and down for 13.5 miles. The hike was not bad just rocky. I made it into the shelter tonight just before it started to pour. It was very warm yesterday but cooled off today.

We passed through Harperâs Ferry which was a great old town. Everything was dated back from 1700-1800. This picture is of the Storer College. Tonight I will stay at Edward Garvey Shelter in Maryland at mile 1031 for the night.

Even though we are experiencing some heavy rains, we had a good day! It was a major milestone for Cruise Control. He used to drive trucks on the I-70 and as he would go under the AT pass he would honk his horn for the hikers on the Appalachian trail. Today we made it there and had many drivers honk their horns as we walked over! Tonight we are at Pine Knobe Shelter at mile marker 1047.7. I have updated the miles to reflect this in the journal. My toe is feeling better, but still on the mend. I am starting to dream of pasta and bread though!
We are at Raven Rock Shelter. We had another day of heavy rain so we decided to stop for the day around 3:00

We made it to the Rocky Mountain Shelter at mile 1080.6. We got in just before it down-poured. We received some trail magic today from a guy from Ohio. He gave us bacon cheeseburgers, they were delicious. We also crossed the MasonÂ Dixon Line and entered Pennsylvania!

We have been seeing a lot of Boy Scouts coming into the shelters at night. They look like they are a little shell shocked after being wet all day with all the rain we have gotten. Today was a beautiful day however, very nice. It was a pleasant stop at Quarry Gap, the shelter has a good care taker, nice spot.

We spent Monday night at Birch Run Shelter, mile 1093. Today I passed the 1100 mile mark. I did the ice cream challenge with peanut butter cup ice cream. I ate everything that you see in the picture, however it was a pint short, I didn't get the other pint. I'm heading to James Fry Shelter tonight, mile 1110. We will be meeting Cruise's friend Keith in Boiling Springs tomorrow for a visit, steaks and beer. We have been meeting Ninja Tortoise in the shelters at night. He started hiking from Key West on January 10th. He is hiking the Appalachian Trail and then continuing into Quebec. He carries only a day pack. He lives in Eugene, Oregon. He hiked the Pacific Crest Trail last year. He likes elk hunting and talked about "noodling" for catfish in Arkansas, they catch the catfish with their hands in the mud. 
The toughest part of my hike so far was coming down off Dragon Tooth. It was the most technical hike downhill. The best times was at McAfee Knob and getting a bacon cheeseburger from trail angels in the gap.
Thank you Dawn, Keith and Owen for the excellent dinner and great hospitality Wednesday night. The steaks and chicken cooked on the Pit Boss were terrific.
We stayed at this hotel last night. It is one of the oldest hotels on the trail, opened in 1930. We are in Duncannon, PA. It's not exactly a 5 star hotel but at the end of a 27 mile day, it's heaven!

Yesterday into Rausch Gap mining area. They had previously gotten 6 inches of rain and we had to walk through ankle deep water for a good while. Then we spent the night at 501 shelter, mile marker 1194. Today we are at Eagles Nest. Iâm updating the mileage over the past couple of days.

We are at Windsor Furnace Shelter. We walked into Port Clinton for supplies and to meet Cathy, Erin and Cathy's sister Sharon for lunch. They are in Philadelphia helping Hayley and Laurie move into their new apartment. It was only a little over an hour from where we were. We had lunch and they brought us back to the trail head. It was good to be with them. I have contacted the Gregory backpack company. The lumbar support on my pack has broken down. They have agreed to a one time replacement of my pack and will be shipping me a new one.

We are camping trail side tonight. We had a climb this morning in some heavy rain and decided to stop and take a break for lunch. After the weather had cleared out I was able to get this photo looking down on Lehigh Valley. We started out again and then the thunderstorms rolled in. We decided to call it a day and just camp trail side. Last night we were at Tripoli campsite, mile marker 1247.

We are at Kirkridge Shelter for the night. One thing I realized while hiking through Pennsylvania, big rocks are ok, small rocks, not so much. The big rocks I can jump, the small rocks are tough on the feet.

Yesterday we hiked to the trail head and Erica (Dave and Nancy Angell's daughter) picked us up. She had arranged for us to stay at an Air B& B. Thank you Erica, Mike, Clara and Penelope (their dog) for providing us with a great place to stay, shower, great meal and excellent company. It gave us the pleasant sense of home for the day. Mike took us back to the trail head this morning. We are thankful for good friends and the refreshing change in the weather. We will be crossing over into New Jersey today.

We hiked to Rattle Snake Mountain, into New Jersey now. It was a beautiful day to hike with the low humidity and cooler temperatures. I have updated the miles for Friday and Saturday total, we did 22 miles to our current location.
I'm into Rutherford Shelter for the evening It was another pleasant weather day for hiking.

We arrived at High Point State Park in New Jersey this morning. We plan on crossing into New York State tomorrow. Tonight we are at Pochuck Mountain Shelter. We resupplied at Shop Rite. A trail angel drove us there. After we were done, outside Shop Rite, a lady came to us and asked if we were thru hikers and offered us a ride back to the trail and gave us food. Thanks to all the trail magic, we were able to get in our miles and get the supplies we needed.
I'm in New York!!! Yes, Yes, Yes! It feels good, I've walked from Georgia to New York! Camping trail side tonight at mile marker 1373
We stayed at William Brien Shelter last night, mile marker 1397.
I had a nice cold shower and washed my shirt and shorts at Graymour Spiritual Life Center.
We are camping for the night in the ball field at Graymour.
This morning we hiked into Bear Mountain Park. We were greeted by friends Stanley, Bill, Karen, Daniel, Kevin and Dee. Thank you all so much, so nice.
We are at mile marker 1425. We went to the State Park, Canopus Lake where we went swimming and ate grill cheese from concession stand. The grill cheese was delicious!

Today we hiked to the trail head at long hill road in Hopewell. Tony Pignataro met us at 7:30 am on the trail for a couple beers! It was great to see him and we are so thankful that he met us and for all his encouragement along the way. Then my trail angel (Cathy), Hayley and Laurie picked Cruise and I up and we all went to Highland for a stop at my cousin Salâs bar and a much needed trim at the barber! Had a great time there, we then headed to 3 guys pizza for a slice and then home. We were able to resupply at Shop Rite and get cleaned up at home. Got a new pack, poles and shoes. It was almost too good to be home. Even got to sleep in my own bed! We headed to church at night and then had a great steak and corn dinner with the family including my sister Lori and brother-in-law Richie. Nothing like a shower, bed, good food, family and a key lime pie too!
Thank you Tony for meeting us and for the trail magic!
Had a great dinner at home with family!

After an enjoyable time at home, Cruise and I were back at the trail at 6:30 Sunday morning. I not only have new supplies, I have some special homemade supplies that were given to me. Thank you Adele and Jon, for the "Hiker Biker Bars" and the "Hard Tack Crackers". I know they will give me the much needed energy that I'm going to need. Thank you also, to Monica and Dominick for the delicious Banana Bread and Chocolate Chip Cookies. Monica, those cookies are always just so amazing. Thank you all for the trail magic. When we got to the trail, Eric, Tony and his daughter Kathryn were there waiting for us and hiked twelve miles of the trail. At that point Dave Angell met us and supplied us with lunch. The trail magic just keeps on coming! Thank you all so much. Cruise and I continued on after that, hiked another seven miles and were in for the night.
Tonight we are at Mt. Algo Shelter, in Connecticut. It was extremely humid today.
Tonight we are at Pine Swamp Shelter. We walked along the Housatonic River, very pretty. We got a much welcomed thunderstorm that dropped the humidity.
We are at Riga shelter tonight. We stopped in Salisbury, Connecticut to buy supplies. It was a beautiful day today.
Sunrise at Riga Shelter. Â We are at Tom Leonard Shelter tonight in Massachusetts. Water is very hard to come by.
We are in Lee, Massachusetts tonight. Crossing 90 was a highlight for me. We were able to find water more easily today. I was stung by a couple of bees but I'm fine. I put mud on it.
Iâm at Kay Wood Shelter. We had trail magic from Rob Casper, we had previously met him on May 14th. We had seen him in Tennessee and he mentioned he would be in Massachusetts.
We are in for the night at the Mark Noepel Shelter. We walked a short way into town, Cheshire, Massachusetts, for lunch and supplies today.
Monday we crossed over into Vermont in heavy rain. We stayed at Seth Warner Shelter. Tonight we are staying at Goddard Shelter
On Wednesday we hiked 20 miles and spent the night at Stratton Shelter.
Thursday evening, we are at Peru Shelter, 21 miles for the day.

Friday night we were at Minerva Hinchey Shelter, heading into the Rutland, Vermont area. We have been getting a lot of rain and walking through ankle deep mud. My daughter Erin will be picking us up Sunday morning. We are looking forward to it. Tonight we are at Churchill Scott Shelter

Erin picked us up this morning at Route 100 in Killington with Heady Topper on ice. We spent the day with Erin, Garrett and Jelly enjoying the Mad River Valley. We got to have some Mad taco, creemees, and local steaks. As well as some much deserved rest and relaxation.
We were back on the trail early this morning. Thank you Erin, Garrett and Jelly for the trail magic. This is a view from a lookout in Vermont today.

Last night We stayed at Wintturi Shelter, mile marker 1721. My sister Lisa and brother-in-law Bill arrived in Vermont today. We met up with them this afternoon. They are going to do some hiking with us for a couple of days. We enjoyed a great dinner together tonight. We are staying in a hotel and will head back to the trail early tomorrow morning.
We took a break mid day at this shelter. The scenery has been amazing.

Tonight we are stopping in Hanover, New Hampshire. We were excited to be at the Vermont/New Hampshire border today. It has been great having Lisa and Bill hiking with us and share all that nature has to offer. We took a cab back to the hotel. Erin and Garrett met us there and we are all going out to dinner.
We are back on the trail this morning. The photo is Moose Mountain south peak. Lisa and Bill hiked with us again today. Tonight Cruise and I are at Trapper John Shelter.
Tonight Cruise Control and I are at Ore Hill Campsite. Thank you Lisa and Bill for hiking with us and the trail magic for the previous two days.

We had very heavy rain late yesterday and last night. We decided to just do the 9 miles today into the town of Glencliff, New Hampshire. We needed to dry out the tents so decided to stay at the Glencliff hostel, shower, do laundry and pick up supplies.
We passed the 1800 mile mark today and are headed into Eliza Brook Shelter tonight. We had a good climb today.
It was a beautiful day today. The photo is from earlier this morning. Tonight we are sleeping on top of Lafayette.

Last night we stayed at Zealand Hut. It is a "work for stay" lodge. They gave Cruise and I various chores to do and they fed us and let us spend the night. We hope to be in Gorham, New Hampshire by Saturday.

Last night we stayed at Mispah Hut. It was another "work for stay" lodge. My chore was to work in the pantry, taking all the food off the shelves, clean the shelves and replace the food. We were able to eat any of the leftovers. The food was great, we had pulled pork, couscous, soup and a delicious cake.

This morning we were at the summit of Mt. Washington. We had to forgo our hike for the rest of the day because the weather was extremely bad. There were 50-70 mph winds and torrential rain coming in sideways. The visibility on the trail was maybe a foot to two feet in front of us. We decided to take a shuttle down to Pinkham Notch and stay in the hostel for the night. Tomorrow the weather is supposed to lift with temperatures in the morning around 40 degrees.

We were able to go back to the summit of Mt. Washington Friday morning and continue on. We went to Stealth Camp, mile marker 1871. It was very cold in the morning but it warmed up during the day. Today was another nice day. Tonight we are at Imp Shelter, mile 1884. We plan to reach Maine hopefully by Monday.
Last night we stayed at Rattle River Hostel in Shelburne, New Hampshire. It's a beautiful lodge with nice accommodations.

This is in front of the lodge, it was definitely one of the nicer hostels we have stayed in on the trail. Cruise and I took some time today to map out a tentative schedule for the rest of our hike. Though any one day could change it, our tentative date to reach Mt. Katahdin is September 9th.
We are in Maine, one state to go, very happy. We are staying at the Carlo Col Shelter tonight.

After a very tough day of hiking, we are at Speck Pond and shelter. We made it through the Mahoosuc Notch and the Mahoosuc Arm, as it is referred to. We had early morning rain but then it cleared. It is very rugged terrain where we had to climb up, through and under boulders.

Tonight we are stealth camping by a waterfall. Tomorrow by friend Dave will be picking us up for a three day vacation from hiking. My first full time off after 119 days of hiking. We will be bringing Cruise to the airport on Friday, he goes to his daughter's wedding on Saturday, flies back on Sunday and we will be back on the trail on Monday. I'm looking forward to relaxing and eating all weekend!
I'm posting a couple of photos from our hike this week into Speck Pond.
This is a foggy view, but still beautiful.

I enjoyed the time with Dave. We are staying at Wild Duck Campground. We bought lunch from Harbor Fish Market. We bought fresh lobster, shrimp and smoked blue fish and a loaf of fresh bread. It was great, I do miss bread.
I had a beer after our fish dinner at Port Hole, Lone Pine brewed in Portland.
I don't get this on the trail!
It was a beautiful view at the beach, very relaxing
Maybe the salt water will help my sore, tired feet. They have just about three weeks left in them!!

Tonight we are at Sabbath Bay Pond Shelter. Thank you Dave Angell for taking care of Cruise and I this past weekend. We truly appreciate you taking Cruise to and from the airport so that he was able to go to his daughter's wedding and driving me around Portland , giving me much needed relaxation and nutrition. We are back on the trail, Mt. Katahdin here we come!
We actually stayed Monday night at Sabbath Bay Pond Shelter, Tuesday night we stayed at Redington Campsite. We climbed Saddleback during the hike.
Wednesday night we stayed at Spaulding Mountain lean-to. We are getting heavy rain this morning.

We are in Stratton, Maine. We made it to mile marker 2002.7. According to the Appalachian Trail regulations, once a hiker reaches 2000 miles they are considered a thru hiker. Tonight we are staying at Stratton Hostel.
Cruise with his daughters at the wedding last Saturday.
Last night we were at Horn Pond lean-to, mile 2007. Â This morning we are at the top of Bigelow.
This afternoon we hiked to Flagstaff Lake.
Tonight we are camping on the shore of the lake, very nice spot.
Sunset on the lake.
Sunday night we stayed at Pierce Pond lean-to. We fell asleep listening to the loons on the pond. This morning we crossed the Kennebec.

This morning we forged the Kennebec river. The trail crosses the river. The Appalachian Trail Conservancy provides the canoes for the AT hikers. This afternoon we are heading to Bald Mountain lean-to.

Tuesday we hiked 13 miles and stayed at Horseshoe Canyon lean-to, mile marker 2067. Â Today we hiked another 9 miles into Munson, Maine. I picked up my last box of shipped supplies from home. Â  Tonight and tomorrow night we will be staying at Shawâs Hostel. Â Friday we start the Hundred-Mile Wilderness. It is the section of the AT that runs from Munson to Abol Bridge, just south of Baxter State Park. There are no main roads that go into the area, just a few logging roads. We plan to stay at Whitehouse Landing on Tuesday night, where everything is shipped in by boat. We hope to be at Abol Bridge Campsite next Thursday.

Since it works with our schedule to finish on September 9th, in anticipation of starting the Hundred-Mile Wilderness tomorrow, we decided to take a break today and relax. We are prepped and ready to go. I will update with information when the cell reception allows.
Tonight we are at Long Pond Lean-to. Â Less than 100 miles to go.
This is our view this morning from Barren Mountain.
Tonight we are at Chairback Gap lean-to. The trail so far has been pretty good.
Tonight we are staying at Logan Brook lean-to.
This was where we camped on Monday night and swam in the swimming hole.
This sign is posted for the Hundred-Mile Wilderness.
